label: real
article:
SARS-CoV-2 is a global problem. Some are reminded of the Spanish flu pandemic, one of the largest catastrophes of the 20th century. What can we learn from history?
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
History may not
repeat itself. But it is possible to see its reflection in what we are
experiencing today. Has there ever before been a pandemic like the current one?
Or is it completely unprecedented? It is helpful to take a look back in time to
see what lessons history might have for us.
Mark Honigsbaum is
a person who has turned to the past. In his book, The Pandemic
Century, he examines significant disease outbreaks from the 20th and
early 21st centuries. "No two pandemics are exactly alike,"
Honigsbaum said in a recent telephone conversation, "but there are lots of
parallels between COVID-19 and the Spanish flu in 1918." 
It is a comment
that isn't exactly hopeful. The Spanish flu, after all, was one of the largest
catastrophes of the last century. As World War I came to an end, around a third
of the global population became infected with the virus that caused the flu,
and many of them suffered from severe pneumonia. Their skin turned blue, blood
oozed out of their noses and they died gasping for breath ‚Äì in Mumbai, in New York, in Stuttgart and all around the world. Rough estimates hold that around
50 million people lost their lives to the Spanish flu, a number equivalent to
between 2.5 and 5 percent of the global population at the time.
In contrast to
the acute respiratory disease COVID-19, which got its start in the Chinese city
of Wuhan ‚Äì in connection, it is believed, to a market that traded in wild
animals of a kind that could have transmitted the virus to humans ‚Äì we don't
know precisely where the Spanish flu originated. Historians, virologists and
biologists have found indications that a precursor to the deadly flu pathogen was
already circulating in the years prior to the deadly 1918 pandemic. One trail
leads back to a British military base in the northern French town of √âtaples. "The
base was crowded with soldiers," wrote virologists in a 2014 study (Isirv:
Wever & Van Bergen, 2014). It "was situated near sea marshes with
abundant migratory birds, had many farms nearby with pigs, ducks and geese
reserved as food for soldiers (‚Ä¶). These conditions might have contributed to
an outbreak of acute respiratory infection."
Genetic analyses
of the few tissue samples that we have from people who came down with the Spanish
flu do, indeed, show that the virus's genotype contains gene segments that
likely originated in birds (Proceedings of the American Philosophical
Society: Taubenberger, 2006). Inordinately close proximity between humans
and animals is often the jumping-off point for pandemics and many diseases that
pose a threat to humans ‚Äì an estimated 60 percent (DFID: Grace et al.,
2021) ‚Äì are such "zoonoses." The term refers to illnesses whose
pathogens, often viruses, suddenly jump from an animal to a human. That was the
case with the Spanish flu, with bushmeat that triggered Ebola outbreaks and
with COVID-19. We don't yet know for sure what creature was the source for the
current virus, but it is likely that the vector animal initially received the
virus from a bat. That theory is the result of genetic analysis performed on
the pathogen (Nature Medicine: Andersen et al., 2020).
The world is much
more closely linked today than it was in 1918. Prior to the outbreak, hundreds
of flights a week took off from Wuhan to destinations around the world; and with
its New Silk Road initiative, China has established tight ties with myriad places
all over the world. But 1918 was also a year in which far-flung corners of the
world came closer together, primarily because of the war. In British military
camps in northern France, soldiers from India's Punjab, Sierra Leone and
Nigeria shared close quarters with the British and French, not to mention
laborers from China and Vietnam. Many of them carried the virus back home, thus
dispersing it across the globe. Indeed, the spread was similar to the way
SARS-CoV-2 advanced along trade and tourism routes in recent weeks.
The virus that
triggered the Spanish flu pandemic must have mutated in the months and years
prior to March 1918 from a harmless flu pathogen to a deadly virus. Soldiers
were packed so closely together in the trenches and they died so quickly that
the flu virus had to adapt, says biologist Paul Ewald (Public Health Reports:
Byerly, 2010). From an evolutionary perspective, it is advantageous for viruses
to refrain from killing their hosts since they need living humans and animals
to multiply and spread. But in 1918, because soldiers were dying so quickly of
other causes ‚Äì such as gunfire, typhoid fever, severe diarrhea and complications
from trench foot ‚Äì a form of virus developed that was able to multiply
extremely quickly. But the more rapidly it multiplied, the more deadly it
became. And it was this fatal variation that spread at the end of the war.
In a 2019 article
for the medical journal The Lancet, pandemic historian Honigsbaum quotes
a passage from the play The Doctor's Dilemma by George Bernhard
Shaw. "The characteristic microbe of a disease might be a symptom instead
of a cause," the passage reads (The Lancet: Honigsbaum, 2019). In
other words, the Spanish flu could be a symptom of global military conflict ‚Äì in
part because it affected many young soldiers who were packed together under
poor conditions in drafty military camps, but also because the heavily censored
wartime press hardly wrote about the outbreak at all. The global public, in
other words, was long kept in the dark about the initial infections.
By contrast,
Honigsbaum sees SARS-CoV-2 as a symptom of humans having pushed too far into
the habitats of wild animals and of the close international links that define
today's world. But he also believes that the current pandemic shows the degree
to which we have "neglected basic research." The year 2002 also saw
the outbreak of a coronavirus: the pathogen that caused severe acute
respiratory syndrome, or SARS. It was a close relative of SARS-CoV-2, which is
now ricocheting around the world and causing COVID-19. Even though that was
many years ago, we still have no vaccine for SARS. One of the reasons for that
failure was money. A team led by Peter Hotez, dean of the National School of
Tropical Medicine in Houston, presented a vaccine candidate four years ago (Human
Vaccines & Immunotherapeutics: Chen et al., 2014). But when it came
time for a clinical study to determine its safety and effectiveness, defined by
its ability to trigger the production of antibodies, nobody could be found who
was willing to finance it.
That, from
today's perspective, was a bad mistake. Not just because SARS could reappear at
any moment, but also because the SARS virus and the novel coronavirus are
genetically quite similar. It is very possible that a SARS vaccine may also
have provided some protection against SARS-CoV-2 (see also: Nature: Zhou
et al., 2020).
There are, of
course, vast differences between the Spanish flu ‚Äì essentially a severe form of
the sickness that infects millions every year ‚Äì and the novel coronavirus. Not
only is it a completely different kind of virus, but virologists also believe
that ‚Äì in contrast to flu viruses ‚Äì higher temperatures and lower humidity
levels won't have much of an effect on SARS-CoV-2 (for example Medrxiv:
Oliveiros et al., 2020). That means that we should not pin our hopes on the
pandemic vanishing this spring. On top of that is the fact that SARS-CoV-2 is
apparently much more contagious than the flu (Medrxiv: Read et al.,
2020), even if some researchers point out that the Spanish flu, for its part,
was much more contagious than other waves of flu (Journal of Infectious
Diseases: Andreasen et al., 2008). But perhaps the most important
difference is that in 1918, it was primarily people between the ages of 20 and
40 who died from the disease. COVID-19, by contrast, poses particular dangers
to seniors and people with pre-existing conditions ‚Äì which doesn't, of course,
mean that younger people cannot also die from the disease.
Graphs showing
the rise in life expectancy throughout the 20th century all have a sharp downward
spike between 1917 and 1919. Even if a large share of the world were to fall
ill with COVID-19 in the coming months and 1 percent of all infected people
were to die, we still wouldn't see such a dramatic spike. This is because the
effect on average life expectancy isn't as great when the elderly die, since
they are already close to the expected extent of their lives. Furthermore, a
comparison of the (fragmentary) data on Spanish flu's mortality rate with the
(extremely premature) data on SARS-CoV-2 reveals that the latter illness may be
only half as deadly (Emerging Infectious Diseases: Taubenberger &
Morens, 2006 and Nature Medicine: Wu et al., 2020).
And there is another
thing that is completely different this time around: Whereas newspapers were
censored in 1918, and were anyway primarily focused on the war, the novel
coronavirus is receiving exhaustive coverage this time around. Since January,
the world has been closely following the pathogen's every move and precisely
monitoring efforts being made to stop its spread: Wuhan transformed into a
ghost town; doctors collapsing from exhaustion; all corners of the world
affected; borders closing; public life vanishing from the streets. People are
sitting at home staring into their smartphones and televisions. It's a bit like
reality TV, just that we are all on the verge of being yanked into the action.
Peak panic is
everywhere ‚Äì in the media, on the stock markets and in the parliaments. Swine
flu, that particularly contagious flu epidemic that began in 2009, also hit the
headlines, as did the large Ebola outbreak in 2014-2015, but it was nothing
like the current coverage. It seems likely that COVID-19's media dominance trumps
that of every pandemic that came before it. People and politicians around the
world are only talking about one thing: corona. It is a phenomenon that Thomas
Zimmer, a historian at the University of Freiburg and an expert in
international health policy, is keeping an eye on. He had actually been
planning on moving to the United States in a few weeks to take up a
professorship at Georgetown University, but flying to the U.S. is no longer
possible. Regarding the closure of schools, bars, shops and international
borders, Zimmer says: "In the history of the Federal Republic of Germany,
there has never been such a massive political reaction to a health
problem."
Honigsbaum also
says: "We are  entering uncharterted
territory." He compares the COVID-19 pandemic to World War II ‚Äì not in
terms of the destruction the violence left behind but in terms of the social
and economic consequences. We won't know whether he is correct for several
months, or perhaps even several years.
What, though, can
we actually learn from past epidemics?
The first thing
is that once a pandemic has passed, the world must do all it can to prepare for
the next one. There were sufficient warnings in the recent past of an impending
pandemic, including Ebola, Nipah, SARS, MERS and bird flu ‚Äì yet not enough was
done. For years, scientists have been warning of a possible outbreak of the
kind we are now seeing. And for just as long, the World Health Organization
(WHO) has been telling its member states to take more decisive steps to
prepare. Just last September, a report compiled by the Global Preparedness Monitoring
Board noted: "The world is not prepared for a fast-moving, virulent
respiratory pathogen pandemic." Progress has been made, the report noted,
"but current efforts remain grossly insufficient." It argued that
there is a lack of monitoring systems, a shortage of research and development
capacity and an absence of a strong, public health service that can track
chains of infections.
When it comes to
preparation, the focus at the moment, of course, is not primarily on the next
pandemic but on the next wave of COVID-19 infections. Pandemics proceed in
waves. The Spanish flu, for example, had three severe waves: the first in
spring 1918, a particularly severe one in fall and winter of 1918, and a final
wave in 1919 (New England Journal of Medicine: Miller et al., 2009). The
novel coronavirus pandemic could develop similarly. Viruses that travel around
the world, after all, aren't unlike a pinball: They jump from one side of the
world to the next, only to then return after a short period of time to trigger
the next outbreak at the place originally infected.
The
Psychology of the Pandemic
And past
outbreaks have another thing to teach us as well: We have to act quickly. Very
quickly. Mike Ryan, the head of WHO's Health Emergencies Program who helped contain
several Ebola outbreaks, says: "Be fast. Have no regrets." He also
argues that "speed trumps perfection. (‚Ä¶) The greatest error is to be
paralyzed by the fear of failure." Ryan's message casts a different light
on what is currently going on in Germany and Europe. Nobody knows, of course,
what effect school closures will have. But one lesson of pandemics is that we
can't wait. We have to take action. It is a message supported by the data:
Cities and municipalities in the U.S. that quickly shut schools and churches,
and which banned public events, experienced less severe outbreaks of the
Spanish flu (PNAS: Hatchett et al., 2007).
Science has surely
already made significant progress. Researchers around the world are working
together and producing important findings in record time ‚Äì likely faster than
ever before. It only took a few weeks for the pathogen to be identified and for
a test to be developed. Data about patients has been gathered under the most
difficult of conditions and clinical studies of possible therapies are underway.
The first results are expected shortly ‚Äì and who knows, it could even be that a
drug developed for a different deadly virus could also help against SARS-CoV-2.
One candidate is remdesivir, which was developed to fight Ebola. Another is
favipiravir (Proceedings of the Japan Academy: Furuta et al., 2017),
which was originally intended to treat the flu.
Science has also
come closer to solving another riddle: Namely the question as to why it was
mostly young people who succumbed to Spanish flu. It could have to do with the
fact that people born around 1890 ‚Äì a cohort for whom the 1918 influenza virus
proved particularly deadly ‚Äì had their first experience with the flu with a virus
from the H3N8 group (Plos Pathogens: Gagnon et al., 2015). Decades
later, when their immune systems found themselves confronted with the H1N1
virus that caused the Spanish flu, they were unable to deal with it. Our immune
systems are, to a certain extent, shaped by the first flu virus they come into
contact with, which has an effect on how they react to other influenza
pathogens. Whether the same is true for coronaviruses remains a matter of
speculation. But Justin Lessler, who conducts research into the phenomenon,
known as "imprinting," told the New Yorker that he believes it
is. And that could help us understand why some people react more severely to
the virus than others.
We also know a
lot more today about what goes on in people's minds, and how they change their
behaviors when a dangerous pathogen is racing around the world and directly
affecting their daily lives. Steven Taylor is a clinical psychologist at the
University of British Columbia and the author of The Psychology of
Pandemics, perhaps the most comprehensive book on the subject. "The burgeoning
of xenophobia and panic buying, or the demand for quack remedies ‚Äì we've seen
all of that in previous pandemics," he says, adding that such knowledge
helps to react to such phenomena this time around. Governments can launch
information campaigns, for example, or supermarkets can adapt supply chains to
account for panic buying.
In previous
epidemics, such as during the swine flu (H1N1) scare in 2009, it became
apparent, says Taylor, that a lot of people head to the hospital out of fear.
That is something that must be prevented this time around, he says, because it overwhelms
the health-care system.
But perhaps the
most important lesson from the history of pandemics is a different one. Taylor says
that Hollywood films about pandemics have it wrong. There isn't a complete
societal collapse, we don't become overwhelmed by chaos and revert to our base
instincts. Rather, he says, it has repeatedly been observed that people help
each other and are nice to each other. During pandemics, he says, it can be
seen over and over again just how much solidarity people exhibit.
Translated by
Charles Hawley
